qas.question: WHat is the biggest factor in the ECB maintaining price stability?
Who gets to interview and question prospective board members?
Why do EU institutions and national governments have to respect the independence of the ECB?
How is the ECB held accountable for it's actions?

answers.text: bound to publish reports on its activities and has to address its annual report to the European Parliament

qas.question: Who never gets to interview and question prospective board members?
Why do EU institutions and national governments never respect the dependence of the ECB?

plausible_answers.text: bound to publish reports on its activities and has to address its annual report to the European Parliament

qas.question: How is the ECB not held accountable for it's actions?

context: The <a0_0>independence<a0_0/> of the ECB is instrumental in maintaining price stability. Not only must the bank not seek influence, but EU institutions and national governments are <a2_0><b5_0>bound by the treaties<b5_0/><a2_0/> to respect the ECB's independence. To offer some accountability, the ECB is <a3_0><b6_0>bound to publish reports on its activities and has to address its annual report to the European Parliament<b6_0/><a3_0/>, the European Commission, the Council of the European Union and the European Council. <a1_0><b4_0>The European Parliament<b4_0/><a1_0/> also gets to question and then issue its opinion on candidates to the executive board.
